awd_abstract_narration:
This award is made as part of the FY 2018 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Kyle Hayden is " Submanifolds of complex, symplectic, and symplectic manifolds and the mapping class group". The host institution for the fellowship is Columbia University and the sponsoring scientist is Mohammed Abouzaid.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This report concerns the NSF PostDoctoral Research Fellowship held during the period 8/1/18- 6/30/21. Research was conducted in the mathematical disciplines of topology and contact/symplectic geometry. In addition to directly supporting the PI’s research, the resources furnished by the award were used to create research opportunities for undergraduates and put towards the dissemination of research-level mathematics to undergraduate students.

Differential topology is a field that studies objects and spaces called manifolds. These are objects like the circle, sphere, or torus — boring and essentially flat when you zoom in, yet interesting when you step back. There are infinitely many different manifolds, and they exist in all dimensions. In some very important ways, topology often turns out to be subtlest for 3- and 4-dimensional spaces — even subtler than in higher dimensions. 

One way to study a manifold is to investigate the lower-dimensional manifolds (like circles and surfaces) that sit inside of it, especially knotted circles in 3-space and 2-dimensional surfaces inside of 4-space.  The biggest open question in 4-dimensional topology is the Poincaré conjecture, which seeks to classify the 4-dimensional analogs of the sphere. Many important questions in 4-manifold topology are recast by investigating the types of surfaces that a given knotted circle in 3-space can bound. The work supported by this award developed new tools for understanding the relationship between knots in 3-space and surfaces in 4-space — especially those that arise as solution sets to polynomial equations in two complex variables. These turn out to have beautiful connections to the study of braids, especially quasipositive braids.

In more precise language, some of the primary outcomes of this work included:

  1. Building on a generalization of Rudolph’s “quasipositive” braids to the setting of arbitrary 3-dimensional spaces, and showing that these are precisely the links in the boundaries of Stein domains that bound holomorphic curves in the interiors of the domains (in joint work with Baykur, Etnyre, Hedden, Kawamuro, and Van Horn Morris).
  2. Providing an alternative solution to a long-standing question about “spines” of 4-manifolds in joint work with Piccirillo. These techniques were also used to address an open question about approximating topologically embedded surfaces with smooth or piecewise-linear embeddings.
  3. The PI used new constructive techniques to produce exotically knotted surfaces in the 4-ball (bounded by knots in the 3-sphere), and used these to produce the first examples of smoothly exotically knotted complex curves.
  4. In joint work with Mark and Piccirillo, the showed that certain invariants from knot theory were in fact useful invariants of certain associated 4-dimensional manifolds known as “knot traces”. We then used these invariants to distinguish certain simple new examples of exotic 4-manifolds.

The PI also used this support to conduct three research projects with undergraduates at Columbia University (for a total of 10 students). Several of these research mentees have continued onto graduate school, including multiple continuing on in this research area.


Last Modified: 05/23/2024
Modified by: Kyle Hayden

In addition to directly supporting the PIs research, the resources furnished by the award were used to create research opportunities for undergraduates and put towards the dissemination of research-level mathematics to undergraduate students.


Differential topology is a field that studies objects and spaces called manifolds. These are objects like the circle, sphere, or torus  boring and essentially flat when you zoom in, yet interesting when you step back. There are infinitely many different manifolds, and they exist in all dimensions. In some very important ways, topology often turns out to be subtlest for 3- and 4-dimensional spaces  even subtler than in higher dimensions.


One way to study a manifold is to investigate the lower-dimensional manifolds (like circles and surfaces) that sit inside of it, especially knotted circles in 3-space and 2-dimensional surfaces inside of 4-space. Many important questions in 4-manifold topology are recast by investigating the types of surfaces that a given knotted circle in 3-space can bound. The work supported by this award developed new tools for understanding the relationship between knots in 3-space and surfaces in 4-space  especially those that arise as solution sets to polynomial equations in two complex variables. In more precise language, some of the primary outcomes of this work included:

Building on a generalization of Rudolphs quasipositive braids to the setting of arbitrary 3-dimensional spaces, and showing that these are precisely the links in the boundaries of Stein domains that bound holomorphic curves in the interiors of the domains (in joint work with Baykur, Etnyre, Hedden, Kawamuro, and Van Horn Morris).

The PI used new constructive techniques to produce exotically knotted surfaces in the 4-ball (bounded by knots in the 3-sphere), and used these to produce the first examples of smoothly exotically knotted complex curves.
In joint work with Mark and Piccirillo, the showed that certain invariants from knot theory were in fact useful invariants of certain associated 4-dimensional manifolds known as knot traces. We then used these invariants to distinguish certain simple new examples of exotic 4-manifolds.



The PI also used this support to conduct three research projects with undergraduates at Columbia University (for a total of 10 students). Several of these research mentees have continued onto graduate school, including multiple continuing on in this research area.					Last Modified: 05/23/2024
